{
  "name": "Social Golfer Problem with Couples and Key Persons",
  "description": "The Social Golfer Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. The problem is to seat a set of golfers at a set of tables, with the constraint that no two golfers can sit at the same table more than once. In this variation, there are couples that cannot sit at the same table, and key persons that also cannot sit at the same table. The objective is to minimize the sum of the table numbers of the couples.",
  "variables": "table[t] (set of PERSON), seat[p] (TABLE), obj (int)",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables are: table[t], which represents the set of persons seated at table t; seat[p], which represents the table at which person p is seated; and obj, which is the objective function value, representing the sum of the table numbers of the couples.",
  "constraints": "global_cardinality_low_up(seat, [t|t in TABLE], [0|t in TABLE], [S|t in TABLE]), not_same_table(couples[c,1], couples[c,2]), not_same_table(p1, p2) for p1, p2 in key where p1 < p2, p in table[t] <-> seat[p] = t",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: each table has between 0 and S persons seated; each couple cannot sit at the same table; each pair of key persons cannot sit at the same table; and a person is seated at a table if and only if the person's seat is assigned to that table.",
  "objective": "minimize obj"
}
```

{
  "name": "Langford's Problem",
  "description": "Langford's problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. It involves arranging m copies of the digits 1 to n in a sequence of length m*n, such that any two consecutive copies of digit k are separated by k other digits. The problem is named after C. Dudley Langford, who first proposed it in 1958.",
  "variables": "x[d,c], d ∈ {1..n}, c ∈ {1..m}",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables x[d,c] represent the position in the sequence where the c-th copy of digit d is placed.",
  "constraints": "alldifferent([x[d,c] | d in DIG, c in COPY]), x[d,c+1] = x[d,c] + d + 1, d ∈ {1..n}, c ∈ {1..m-1}",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: (1) all positions in the sequence must be distinct (alldifferent constraint), and (2) for each digit d, the c+1-th copy of d must be placed d+1 positions after the c-th copy of d.",
  "objective": "satisfy"
}
```

Note that the objective of the problem is to find a feasible solution that satisfies all the constraints, rather than to minimize or maximize a specific value.

  "description": "The Set Packing Problem is a classic problem in combinatorial optimization and constraint programming. Given a collection of sets, the goal is to select a subset of these sets such that no two sets in the subset have any elements in common, and the total number of elements in the selected sets is maximized. In this specific model, we are given a universe of elements and a collection of subsets, and we want to select a subset of elements such that each subset contains at most one element from the selected subset.",
  "variables": "x = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_u), where x_i is a variable representing the i-th element in the selected subset.",
  "constraints": "x_i != x_j for all i, j in 1..u where i < j (each element in the selected subset is unique), and sum(j in 1..u)(x_j in s_i) <= 1 for all i in 1..k (each subset contains at most one element from the selected subset).",
  "objective": "maximize sum(x) (maximize the total number of elements in the selected subset)"

{
  "name": "Rectangle Packing Problem with Rotation",
  "description": "The Rectangle Packing Problem with Rotation is a classic problem in constraint programming and operations research. The problem involves packing a set of rectangles of different sizes into a larger rectangle (the roll) with a fixed height and minimum length. Each rectangle can be rotated to fit into the roll. The goal is to minimize the length of the roll used to pack all the rectangles.",
  "variables": "x, y, rot, l",
  "variables_explanation": "x is an array of variables representing the x-coordinate of each rectangle, y is an array of variables representing the y-coordinate of each rectangle, rot is an array of variables representing the rotation of each rectangle (1-4), and l is a variable representing the length of the roll used to pack all the rectangles.",
  "constraints": "∀i ∈ ROOM (shape[i,rot[i]] ≠ {}), ∀i ∈ ROOM (∀r ∈ ROFF (r ∈ shape[i,rot[i]] → (x[i] + d[r,1] + d[r,3] ≤ l ∧ y[i] + d[r,2] + d[r,4] ≤ h))), ∀i,j ∈ ROOM (i < j → (∀r1,r2 ∈ ROFF (r1 ∈ shape[i,rot[i]] ∧ r2 ∈ shape[j,rot[j]] → (x[i] + d[r1,1] + d[r1,3] ≤ x[j] + d[r2,1] ∨ x[j] + d[r2,1] + d[r2,3] ≤ x[i] + d[r1,1] ∨ y[i] + d[r1,2] + d[r1,4] ≤ y[j] + d[r2,2] ∨ y[j] + d[r2,2] + d[r2,4] ≤ y[i] + d[r1,2]))))",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: (1) each rectangle must have a valid shape, (2) each rectangle must fit within the roll, and (3) no two rectangles can overlap. The first constraint ensures that each rectangle has a valid shape by checking that the shape array is not empty for each rectangle. The second constraint ensures that each rectangle fits within the roll by checking that the x and y coordinates of each rectangle plus the size of the rectangle do not exceed the length and height of the roll. The third constraint ensures that no two rectangles overlap by checking that the x and y coordinates of each pair of rectangles do not overlap.",
  "objective": "minimize l"
}

It involves scheduling a set of jobs on a set of machines, where each job consists of a sequence of tasks that must be executed in a specific order. Each task requires a specific machine and has a specific processing time. The goal is to find a schedule that minimizes the makespan, which is the maximum completion time of all jobs.",

  "variables_explanation": "s[j,t] represents the start time of task t in job j, and makespan represents the maximum completion time of all jobs.",

  "constraints_explanation": "The first constraint ensures that tasks within a job are executed in order, i.e., the start time of task t+1 in job j is greater than or equal to the completion time of task t in job j. The second constraint is a disjunctive constraint that ensures that tasks that require the same machine are executed non-overlapping in time. The disjunctive constraint is implemented using the disjunctive.mzn library.",
  "objective": "minimize makespan"
}
```

}

  "variables": "produce[m,c] (m in MACHINE, c in COLOR)",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables represent the production quantity of each color (c) on each machine (m). The production quantity is a non-negative integer that does not exceed half of the machine's daily production capacity (k).",
  "constraints": [
    "∑(c in COLOR) produce[m,c] ≤ k (m in MACHINE)",
    "∑(m in MACHINE) produce[m,c] ≥ l[c] (c in COLOR)",
    "∑(m in MACHINE) produce[m,c] ≤ u[c] (c in COLOR)",
    "produce[m,white] > 0 ∧ produce[m,black] > 0 → produce[m,blue] = 0 (m in MACHINE)",
    "produce[m,blue] ≤ produce[m,red] (m in MACHINE)",
    "produce[m,red] mod 4 = 0 (m in MACHINE)",
    "produce[m,white] mod 3 = 0 (m in MACHINE)"
  ],
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints ensure that: (1) the total production on each machine does not exceed its daily capacity, (2) the minimum production requirement for each color is met, (3) the maximum production limit for each color is not exceeded, (4) if a machine produces white and black items, it cannot produce blue items, (5) the production of blue items on a machine does not exceed the production of red items, (6) the production of red items on a machine is a multiple of 4, and (7) the production of white items on a machine is a multiple of 3.",
  "objective": "maximize ∑(m in MACHINE, c in COLOR) produce[m,c]"
}

Given a set of objects, each with a profit and a size, and a knapsack with a limited capacity, the goal is to select a subset of the objects to include in the knapsack such that the total profit is maximized without exceeding the knapsack's capacity.   "constraints_explanation": "The constraint ensures that the total size of the objects included in the knapsack does not exceed the knapsack's capacity. δ(i ∈ x) is a binary function that is 1 if object i is included in the knapsack and 0 otherwise.",
  "objective": "maximize ∑_{i=1}^{n} profit_i * δ(i ∈ x)"
}

{
  "name": "Traveling Salesman Problem with Precedence Constraints",
  "description": "The Traveling Salesman Problem with Precedence Constraints is a variant of the classic Traveling Salesman Problem. In this problem, we are given a set of cities and their coordinates, as well as a set of precedence constraints that specify the order in which certain cities must be visited. The goal is to find the shortest possible tour that visits each city exactly once and satisfies all the precedence constraints.",
  "variables": "order: CITY → POS, city: POS → CITY",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables are order and city. The order variable is an array that maps each city to its position in the tour, while the city variable is an array that maps each position in the tour to the city that is visited at that position. In other words, order[i] gives the position of city i in the tour, and city[j] gives the city that is visited at position j in the tour.",
  "constraints": "∀i ∈ PREC: order[left[i]] < order[right[i]], inverse(order, city)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are the precedence constraints and the inverse constraint. The precedence constraints specify that for each precedence constraint i, the city left[i] must be visited before the city right[i]. The inverse constraint ensures that the order and city variables are inverses of each other, meaning that if order[i] = j, then city[j] = i.",
  "objective": "minimize ∑(i=1 to n-1) |coord[city[i]] - coord[city[i+1]]|"
}

{
  "name": "Prisoner Placement Problem",
  "description": "The Prisoner Placement Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. The problem involves placing a set of prisoners in a grid of cells, where each prisoner has a specific cost associated with each cell. The goal is to minimize the total cost of placing all prisoners while satisfying certain constraints. The constraints include ensuring that no two prisoners are placed in adjacent cells, and that female prisoners are placed in the upper half of the grid and male prisoners are placed in the lower half of the grid.",
  "variables": "r[p], c[p] for p in PRISONER",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables r[p] and c[p] represent the row and column of the cell where prisoner p is placed.",
  "constraints": "alldifferent([r[p] * m + c[p] | p in PRISONER]), manhattan(r[p],c[p],r[d],c[d]) > 1 for p in PRISONER, d in danger where p != d, r[p] <= (n + 1) div 2 for p in female, r[p] >= n div 2 + 1 for p in male",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints include: (1) ensuring that each prisoner is placed in a unique cell (alldifferent), (2) ensuring that no two prisoners in the danger set are placed in adjacent cells (manhattan distance > 1), (3) ensuring that female prisoners are placed in the upper half of the grid, and (4) ensuring that male prisoners are placed in the lower half of the grid.",
  "objective": "minimize totalcost = sum(p in PRISONER)(cost[r[p],c[p]])"
}
```

{
  "name": "Set Packing Problem",
  "description": "The Set Packing Problem is a classic problem in combinatorial optimization and constraint programming. Given a collection of subsets of a finite set, the goal is to select a subset of these subsets such that each element of the original set is contained in at most one of the selected subsets. In this specific model, the problem is further constrained by requiring the selected set to have a fixed cardinality, and the objective is to maximize the sum of the elements in the selected set.",
  "variables": "x: a set of elements from 1 to n",
  "variables_explanation": "x is the decision variable representing the set of elements to be selected. It is a subset of the original set of elements from 1 to n.",
  "constraints": "∀i ∈ 1..k (|x ∩ s[i]| ≤ 1), |x| = u",
  "constraints_explanation": "The first constraint ensures that each subset s[i] intersects with the selected set x in at most one element. This is the set packing constraint, which prevents any element from being contained in more than one of the selected subsets. The second constraint fixes the cardinality of the selected set x to u.",
  "objective": "maximize ∑i ∈ x (i)"
}

{
  "name": "K-Median Clustering Problem",
  "description": "The K-Median Clustering Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming and operations research. Given a set of points and their pairwise distances, the goal is to partition the points into k clusters such that the sum of the distances between points in different clusters is maximized, while ensuring that the diameter of each cluster (i.e., the maximum distance between two points in the same cluster) does not exceed a certain threshold. The problem is often used in data analysis and machine learning to identify patterns and structure in data.",
  "variables": "x_i (i in POINT), obj",
  "variables_explanation": "x_i represents the cluster assignment of point i, where x_i is an integer between 1 and k. obj is the objective function value, which represents the sum of the distances between points in different clusters, plus a penalty term for points in the same cluster that are far apart.",
  "constraints": "∀i,j in POINT where i < j ∧ x_i = x_j : dist[i,j] ≤ maxdiam, ∀i in 1..k-1 : min({j | j in POINT ∧ x_j = i}) < min({j | j in POINT ∧ x_j = i+1}), value_precede_chain([i | i in 1..k], x)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The first constraint ensures that the diameter of each cluster does not exceed maxdiam. The second constraint ensures that the points in each cluster are ordered in a way that the first point in cluster i is less than the first point in cluster i+1. The third constraint is a chain constraint that ensures that the points in each cluster are ordered in a way that the first point in cluster i is less than the first point in cluster i+1, and that the points in each cluster are contiguous.",
  "objective": "maximize obj = min(i,j in POINT where i < j) (dist[i,j] + maxdist * (x_i != x_j))"
}
```

{
  "name": "Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "The Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem (RCPSP) is a classic problem in Operations Research and Constraint Programming. It involves scheduling a set of tasks with given durations and precedence constraints, while taking into account the availability of resources. The goal is to find a schedule that minimizes the makespan, i.e., the maximum completion time of all tasks.",
  "variables": "s ∈ {0, ..., t}^n, where s_i is the start time of task i, and t is the total duration of all tasks.",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables represent the start times of the tasks. Each task i has a start time s_i, which is a non-negative integer less than or equal to the total duration t of all tasks.",
  "constraints": "∀i ∈ PREC: s_{pre[i,1]} + d_{pre[i,1]} ≤ s_{pre[i,2]}, ∀i, j ∈ CARPENTRY, i < j: s_i + d_i ≤ s_j ∨ s_j + d_j ≤ s_i",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints can be divided into two types. The first type represents the precedence constraints between tasks. For each precedence constraint, the start time of the predecessor task plus its duration must be less than or equal to the start time of the successor task. The second type represents the non-overlap constraints between tasks that require the same resource (in this case, carpentry). For each pair of tasks that require carpentry, either the start time of the first task plus its duration must be less than or equal to the start time of the second task, or vice versa.",
  "objective": "minimize max(s_i + d_i) over all tasks i"
}
```

{
  "name": "Nurse Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "The Nurse Scheduling Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. It involves scheduling nurses to work different shifts over a period of days, subject to certain constraints. The goal is to find a feasible schedule that satisfies all the constraints.",
  "variables": "x[n,d] ∈ {1, 2, 3} for n ∈ NURSE, d ∈ DAY",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables x[n,d] represent the shift assigned to nurse n on day d. The value of x[n,d] can be 1 (day shift), 2 (night shift), or 3 (day off).",
  "constraints": "∀n ∈ NURSE, d ∈ 1..m-2: (x[n,d] = 2 ∧ x[n,d+1] = 2 → x[n,d+2] = 3) ∧ ∀n ∈ NURSE, d ∈ 1..m-1: (x[n,d] = 2 → x[n,d+1] ≠ 1) ∧ ∀d ∈ DAY: l ≤ ∑(n ∈ NURSE) (x[n,d] = 2) ≤ u",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are as follows: (1) A nurse cannot work two consecutive night shifts without taking a day off on the third day. (2) A nurse cannot work a night shift followed by a day shift on the next day. (3) The number of nurses working the night shift on each day must be within the given bounds [l, u].",
  "objective": "satisfy"
}
```

Note that the objective of this problem is to find a feasible solution that satisfies all the constraints, rather than to minimize or maximize a specific value.

}

  "description": "Langford's Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. It involves arranging m copies of the digits 1 to n in a sequence of length m*n, such that any two consecutive copies of digit k are separated by k other digits. The problem is named after C. Dudley Langford, who first proposed it in 1958.",
  "variables": "x[d,c], y[p]",
  "variables_explanation": "x[d,c] represents the position of the c-th copy of digit d, and y[p] represents the digit at position p in the sequence. The variables x[d,c] and y[p] are used to model the problem, where x[d,c] is a 2D array of variables representing the positions of the copies of the digits, and y[p] is a 1D array of variables representing the sequence of digits.",
  "constraints": "inverse([x[d,c] | d in DIG, c in COPY], y), x[d,c+1] = x[d,c] + d + 1",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints in the problem are: (1) the inverse constraint, which ensures that the sequence of digits y[p] is a permutation of the positions of the copies of the digits x[d,c], and (2) the constraint x[d,c+1] = x[d,c] + d + 1, which ensures that any two consecutive copies of digit k are separated by k other digits.",
  "objective": "satisfy"
}
```

Note that the objective of the problem is to find a satisfying assignment of the variables, rather than to minimize or maximize a specific value. The problem is a feasibility problem, where the goal is to find a solution that satisfies all the constraints.

{
  "name": "Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "The Resource-Constrained Project Scheduling Problem (RCPS) is a classic problem in Operations Research and Constraint Programming. It involves scheduling a set of tasks with given durations and resource requirements, subject to resource constraints and precedence relationships between tasks. The goal is to find a schedule that minimizes the maximum completion time of all tasks.",
  "variables": "s[t] (t in TASK)",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables s[t] represent the start time of each task t in the set of tasks TASK.",
  "constraints": "s[pre[p,1]]+d[pre[p,1]] <= s[pre[p,2]] (p in PREC), cumulative(s,d,[res[r,t]|t in TASK],L[r]) (r in RESOURCE)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The first set of constraints enforces the precedence relationships between tasks, ensuring that a task cannot start before its predecessor has finished. The second set of constraints enforces the resource constraints, ensuring that the total resource usage of all tasks at any point in time does not exceed the available resource capacity.",
  "objective": "minimize max(t in TASK)(s[t] + d[t])"
}
```

Note: The cumulative constraint is a built-in constraint in Minizinc that enforces the cumulative resource constraint. It is defined in the cumulative.mzn file, which is included in the model.

{
  "name": "Job Shop Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "The Job Shop Scheduling Problem is a classic problem in Operations Research and Computer Science. It involves scheduling a set of jobs on a set of machines, where each job consists of a sequence of tasks that must be performed in a specific order. Each task requires a specific machine and has a specific processing time. The goal is to find a schedule that minimizes the makespan, which is the maximum completion time of all jobs.",
  "variables": "s[j,t] (start time of task t in job j), makespan (maximum completion time of all jobs)",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables are the start times of each task in each job, represented by s[j,t], and the makespan, which is the maximum completion time of all jobs. The start times are used to determine the schedule of tasks on each machine, and the makespan is used to evaluate the quality of the schedule.",
  "constraints": "s[j,t] + d[j,t] <= s[j,t+1] (precedence constraint), disjunctive(ss,dd) (machine capacity constraint)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: (1) precedence constraint: each task in a job must be completed before the next task in the same job can start, represented by s[j,t] + d[j,t] <= s[j,t+1]; (2) machine capacity constraint: each machine can only process one task at a time, represented by the disjunctive constraint disjunctive(ss,dd), where ss is the array of start times of tasks on machine ma, and dd is the array of processing times of tasks on machine ma.",
  "objective": "minimize makespan"
}
```

{
  "name": "Stable Roommates Problem",
  "description": "The Stable Roommates Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming and computer science. It involves finding a stable matching between a set of agents, where each agent has a preference list of other agents they would like to be matched with. A matching is considered stable if there are no two agents who would prefer to be matched with each other over their current match. The problem is a variation of the Stable Marriage Problem, but without the distinction between men and women.",
  "variables": "a = [a_1, a_2, ..., a_n], where a_i is the ranking of agent i's match",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables a_i represent the ranking of the match for each agent i. The value of a_i is the position in agent i's preference list of their matched agent.",
  "constraints": "a_i <= npref_i + 1, a_i > rank(i, j) -> a_j < rank(j, i), a_i = rank(i, j) -> a_j = rank(j, i)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints ensure that the matching is stable. The first constraint ensures that the ranking of an agent's match is within their preference list. The second constraint ensures that if agent i prefers agent j over their current match, then agent j must prefer their current match over agent i. The third constraint ensures that if agent i is matched with their jth preference, then agent j must be matched with their jth preference as well.",
  "objective": "satisfy"
}
```

Note: The objective of the problem is to find a stable matching, which is a feasible solution that satisfies all the constraints. There is no objective function to minimize or maximize.

  "name": "Social Golfer Problem with Alternating Genders and Age Constraints",
  "description": "The problem is a variation of the Social Golfer Problem, where a group of people need to be arranged in a specific order. The problem has additional constraints that males and females must alternate in the order, and the age difference between consecutive people in the order cannot be more than 10 years. The goal is to find a feasible arrangement that satisfies all the constraints.",
  "variables": "order ∈ {1, ..., n}^n",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variable order is an array of length n, where each element represents the position of a person in the arrangement. The value of order[i] is the person who is assigned to the i-th position in the arrangement.",
  "constraints": "alldifferent(order) ∧ ∀i ∈ {1, ..., n} (i mod 2 = 0 ⇔ gender[order[i]] = female) ∧ ∀i ∈ {1, ..., n-1} (age[order[i+1]] - age[order[i]] ≤ 10)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: (1) alldifferent(order): each person can only be assigned to one position in the arrangement; (2) ∀i ∈ {1, ..., n} (i mod 2 = 0 ⇔ gender[order[i]] = female): males and females must alternate in the arrangement; (3) ∀i ∈ {1, ..., n-1} (age[order[i+1]] - age[order[i]] ≤ 10): the age difference between consecutive people in the arrangement cannot be more than 10 years.",
  "objective": "satisfy"
}
```

Note: The objective of the problem is to find a feasible arrangement that satisfies all the constraints, rather than to minimize or maximize a specific value. Therefore, the objective is simply "satisfy".

  "description": "The 0/1 Knapsack Problem is a classic problem in combinatorial optimization. Given a set of objects, each with a profit and a size, and a knapsack with a limited capacity, the goal is to select a subset of the objects to include in the knapsack such that the total profit is maximized without exceeding the knapsack's capacity. The problem is called 0/1 because each object can either be included (1) or excluded (0) from the knapsack.",
  "variables": "x = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_n), where x_i in {0, 1} for i in 1..n",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables x_i represent whether object i is included (x_i = 1) or excluded (x_i = 0) from the knapsack.",
  "constraints": "∑_{i=1}^{n} size_i * x_i ≤ capacity",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraint represents the capacity constraint of the knapsack, ensuring that the total size of the objects included in the knapsack does not exceed its capacity.",
  "objective": "maximize ∑_{i=1}^{n} profit_i * x_i"
}

{
  "name": "Ship Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "The Ship Scheduling Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming that involves scheduling ships entering and leaving a port through a limited number of channels. The goal is to minimize the total deviation from the desired start times of the ships while ensuring that there are no clashes between ships in the same channel and that the ships are assigned to channels in a way that respects their speed and the length of the channels.",
  "variables": "start[s], end[s], channel[s], next[s], s ∈ SHIP",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables are: start[s], the time when ship s enters the channel; end[s], the time when ship s leaves the channel; channel[s], the channel assigned to ship s; and next[s], the next ship in the same channel as ship s (or a dummy ship).",
  "constraints": "start[s] + len[channel[s]]*speed[s] = end[s], ∀s ∈ SHIP; channel[next[s]] = channel[s], ∀s ∈ SHIP; alldifferent(next); if kind[s] + kind[next[s]] = entering+leaving then end[s] ≤ start[next[s]] else start[s] + speed[s]*leeway ≤ start[next[s]] ∧ end[s] + speed[s]*leeway ≤ end[next[s]], ∀s ∈ SHIP; start[s] ∈ TIME, end[s] ∈ TIME, channel[s] ∈ CHANNEL, next[s] ∈ SHIPE, ∀s ∈ SHIP",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: the time it takes for a ship to traverse the channel is equal to the length of the channel times the speed of the ship; the next ship in the same channel must be assigned to the same channel; all next ships must be different; there are no clashes between ships in the same channel, either when entering and leaving or when both entering or both leaving; and the start and end times, channel, and next ship are all within their respective domains.",
  "objective": "minimize ∑(s ∈ SHIP) |start[s] - desired[s]|"
}
```

  "variables": "x = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_n), where x_i is a boolean variable indicating whether object i is included in the knapsack",
  "constraints": "∑_{i=1}^{n} size_i * x_i ≤ capacity, where this constraint ensures that the total size of the objects included in the knapsack does not exceed the knapsack capacity",
  "objective": "maximize ∑_{i=1}^{n} profit_i * x_i, which represents the total profit of the objects included in the knapsack"
}

{
  "name": "Prisoner Placement Problem",
  "description": "The Prisoner Placement Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming. The problem involves placing a set of prisoners in a grid of cells, with certain constraints on the placement. The prisoners are divided into two groups: male and female, and there are also some prisoners who are considered 'dangerous'. The goal is to place the prisoners in such a way that the total cost of the placement is minimized, while satisfying the constraints. The constraints include ensuring that no two prisoners are placed in the same cell, that male and female prisoners are separated, and that dangerous prisoners are not placed next to other prisoners.",
  "variables": "r[p], c[p] for p in PRISONER",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables r[p] and c[p] represent the row and column of the cell where prisoner p is placed.",
  "constraints": "alldifferent([r[p] * m + c[p] | p in PRISONER]), abs(r[p] - r[d]) + abs(c[p] - c[d]) > 1 for p in PRISONER, d in danger where p != d, r[p] <= (n + 1) div 2 for p in female, r[p] >= n div 2 + 1 for p in male",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints include: (1) ensuring that no two prisoners are placed in the same cell (alldifferent constraint), (2) ensuring that no prisoner is placed next to a dangerous prisoner (abs(r[p] - r[d]) + abs(c[p] - c[d]) > 1), (3) ensuring that female prisoners are placed in the top half of the grid (r[p] <= (n + 1) div 2), and (4) ensuring that male prisoners are placed in the bottom half of the grid (r[p] >= n div 2 + 1).",
  "objective": "minimize totalcost = sum(p in PRISONER)(cost[r[p],c[p]])"
}
```

{
  "name": "Worker Task Assignment and Scheduling Problem",
  "description": "This problem involves assigning tasks to workers and scheduling them in a way that maximizes the total profit. Each worker can be assigned to one task, and each task can be assigned to one worker. Additionally, there are compatibility constraints between workers that must be respected when scheduling tasks. The tasks are divided into pairs, and the workers assigned to each pair must be compatible.",
  "variables": "task[w] ∈ 1..2m, worker[t] ∈ 1..n",
  "variables_explanation": "The decision variables are task[w], which represents the task assigned to worker w, and worker[t], which represents the worker assigned to task t. The task[w] variable can take any value from 1 to 2m, and the worker[t] variable can take any value from 1 to n.",
  "constraints": "∀t ∈ 1..2m-1, t mod m ≠ 0 → compatible[worker[t], worker[t+1]], inverse(task, worker)",
  "constraints_explanation": "The constraints are: (1) the compatibility constraint, which states that for each pair of tasks (t, t+1) where t is not a multiple of m, the workers assigned to these tasks must be compatible; and (2) the inverse constraint, which states that the task[w] and worker[t] variables are inverses of each other, meaning that if task[w] = t, then worker[t] = w, and vice versa.",
  "objective": "maximize ∑(w ∈ 1..n) profit[w, task[w]]"
}
```

  "description": "The Rectangle Packing Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming and operations research. It involves packing a set of rectangles of different sizes into a larger rectangle (the carpet) of fixed height and minimum length. Each rectangle has a specific shape and size, and the goal is to pack all the rectangles into the carpet while minimizing the length of the carpet used.",
  "variables": "x, y, kind, l",

The second constraint is a geometric constraint that ensures that all rectangles are packed within the carpet and do not overlap with each other.   "objective": "minimize l"
}
```

  "description": "The Stable Roommate Problem is a classic problem in constraint programming and computer science. It involves finding a stable matching between a set of agents, where each agent has a preference order over the other agents. A matching is considered stable if there are no two agents who prefer each other over their current partners. The problem is a variation of the Stable Marriage Problem, but without the distinction between men and women.",
  "variables": "a = [a_1, a_2, ..., a_n], where a_i is the partner of agent i",
  "constraints": "a_i ≤ npref_i + 1, ∀i ∈ AGENT (each agent is matched with one of their top npref_i + 1 choices),\n\
                 a_i > rank[i, j] → a_j < rank[j, i], ∀i, j ∈ AGENT, p ∈ 1..npref_i (if agent i prefers agent j over their current partner, then agent j must prefer their current partner over agent i),\n\
                 a_i = rank[i, j] → a_j = rank[j, i], ∀i, j ∈ AGENT, p ∈ 1..npref_i (if agent i is matched with their top choice, then agent j must also be matched with their top choice)",
  "objective": "satisfy (find a stable matching, if one exists)"
}
